ygData.subject: Re: Automatically setting the Speciation Threshold

Hello Kenneth,

It's great to get a response from you personally! I think t=
he reason
the compatability threshold could get so high is because increasi=
ng
that threshold doesn't actually decrease the number of species. At
least=
 not when you keep the list of species in a fixed order and
assign new offs=
pring to the first specie it matches. The effect of
increasing the threshol=
d will then be that all species will lose their
offspring to the first spec=
ie because the threshold is so high that
they all match the first specie.

=
Analyzing the chromosomes revealed that they were not at all spread
out lik=
e crazy. So I think the problem was that at least one
chromosome of each sp=
ecie was not performing bad enough to be killed
off and thus it's specie ne=
ver disappeared. Increasing the threshold
does not have any influence on th=
e decision whether to kill off the
last survivor of a specie, so it just ke=
pt rising without bounds. The
only effect of increasing the threshold was t=
hat all offspring was put
into the first specie, causing the uneven distrib=
ution I was talking
about.

The solution I am currently using is to keep th=
e species sorted by
size (smallest specie first) and adding offspring to th=
e smallest
specie it matches. If it does not match any specie and we alread=
y have
enough species, then increase the compatability threshold to the
min=
imum threshold needed to match it to one of the species.

Further experimen=
tations revealed that this way I got a very nice and
even distribution of c=
hromosomes over the species, but badly
performing species never got extinct=
 because of the fitness sharing.
Badly performing species do decrease in si=
ze, but when they get small
enough, they get assigned enough fitness by fit=
ness sharing and they
survive. So I have now made sure the lowest performin=
g specie is
killed off if it is older than 30 generations, as you did with =
the
robot duel experiments (I'm using the robot duel too, but with larger
t=
eams and some new rules to advocate cooperation).

Greetings,
Bas


BTW: I =
had set the coefficients for excess genes, disjoint genes and
weight differ=
ence to 1, 1, and 2, respectively. Mutation rates are set
such that I get n=
eural networks with a complexity of 100 to 200 after
500 generations (start=
ing with 22 inputs, 3 outputs and one connection).



--- In neat@yahoogrou=
ps.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@c...> wrote:
>
> There are a lot of cre=
ative ideas in this thread that merit looking 
> into.  Ultimately empirica=
l comparisons would be the most revealing 
> when it comes to alternative m=
ethods, and a lot of you present 
> clever hypotheses.
> 
> However, I can'=
t help feeling that something more simple is going 
> wrong in the situatio=
n Bas describes.  That is, I'm not sure the 
> problem is really to do with=
 my original simple speciation scheme.  
> It sounds more like there is a s=
ystem parameter problem.  I'm really 
> wondering why the compatibility thr=
eshold has to go above 40 before 
> species are getting barely inclusive.  =
It sounds like the whole 
> population is spread out (in terms of either to=
pologies or weights, 
> or both) like crazy.  Why would that happen in only=
 100 generations?
> Bas, what is the rate at which you add nodes and links?=
  Also, what 
> is the strength of your mutations?  Finally, what are the 
=
> coefficients of the compatibility distance equation?  (they could be 
> t=
oo big)
> 
> It would be instructive to observe several examples of genomes=
 that 
> are outside of 40 distance from each other.  What is causing that =

> huge distance?  It's possible that structure has been added willy-
> nil=
ly and speciation would thus have no way of handling the 
> explosion.
> 
>=
 In my experience, I have never seen a speciation dynamic so out of 
> cont=
rol as the one Bas describes unless some other parameter is 
> screwy.  The=
refore, while I think all the creativity in this thread 
> is fantastic, I =
think it really isn't addressing the core problem 
> Bas is having.  I coul=
d be wrong, of course.  But it's worth trying 
> to debug the situation a l=
ittle before turning to alternative 
> methods.  (With the rationale that a=
lternative methods would be no 
> more likely to solve an unrelated systemi=
c problem than the original 
> method.)
> 
> Please don't take this as disc=
ouraging the exploration of 
> alternative speciation schemes.  I have to s=
ay that this thread is 
> one of those enlightening and substantive trading=
s of ideas that one 
> rarely encounters on most internet newsgroups.  I'm =
just saying 
> Bas's specific problem might be something else.
> 
> ken
> 
=
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "itsmebas" <Bas@s...> wrote:
> >
> > Hi all,=

> > 
> > I'm evolving an extension of Stanley & Miikulainen's robot duel 
=
> domain
> > in ANJI 2.01, but I'm having trouble setting the speciation 
>=
 threshold.
> > If I set it too high, all of my 100 chromosomes will (of co=
urse) 
> stay
> > in one specie. But when I set it a bit lower, I end up wi=
th 100
> > species of 1 chromosome after some 100 generations. I can't seem=
 to
> > find the golden middle. On his FAQ
> > (http://www.cs.utexas.edu/us=
ers/kstanley/neat.html), Kenneth 
> Stanley
> > himself presents a method t=
o automatically set the speciation
> > threshold by descreasing or increasi=
ng it with, say, 0.3, whenever 
> the
> > number of species becomes more or=
 less than a preset target amount 
> of,
> > say, 10.
> > 
> > However, whe=
n I apply this method (with population size 100 and 
> target
> > species c=
ount 10), then after some 100 generations I end up with 
> 20 to
> > 25 spe=
cies and a speciation threshold of 40 and rising. Of the
> > resulting spec=
ies, one specie contains 50 chromosomes, 10 species
> > contain 5 chromosom=
es or less and 10 species contain just one 
> chromosome.
> > 
> > Has anyo=
ne else encountered such problems before, or have some 
> idea to
> > what =
might be causing this? How do you keep a 'normal' amount of 
> more
> > or =
less equally sized species?
> >
>
